description.narrative: The project development objective of the proposed project, derived from the overarching program objective of NRAP, is to provide year-round access to basic services and facilities in the rural areas of Afghanistan covered by the project. This will be achieved through rehabilitation and maintenance of rural access infrastructure by contracting with the private sector and, to a lesser extent, with the communities. The achievement of the PDO will enhance the well being of the population and promote equitable licit economic growth in the country.

condition.narrative: MPW and MRRD to establish a robust input price database and costs estimation system, satisfactory to the Association
The Recipient shall adopt and thereafter implement the Project in accordance with the Project Implementation Manual, whichincludesa financial management sub-manual and a procurement sub-manual.
The Recipient shall establish a fully functioning MIS for the project
The Recipient shall establish the National Coordination Unit and appoint a project administrator with skills, qualifications,experiences, and TORs satisfactory to the Association
The Recipient shall, throught MRRD and MPW, enter into contracts satisfactory to the Association for the engagement of theImplementation Consultant
The Recipient, through MPW and MRRD, enter into a contract satisfactory to the Association for the engagement of the CapacityBuilding Consultant
develop, adopt and implement a roads network planning and prioritization mechanism, including basic rural access standards androads specifications, satisfactory to the Association

title.narrative: Roads in good and fair condition as a share of total classified roads

comment.narrative: Data is not available currently
date collection is still underway by the client ministries under the successor project.

title.narrative: Number of rural people with access to an all-season road

comment.narrative: Rural accessibility index (% of population whose community located within 2 Km of all season roads) from National RuralVulnerability Analysis (NRVA) 2007/08 was at 61.4 %. This figure was obtained from preliminary analysis of the data of NRVA2007/08 and is notconsidered very accurate. Accurate reporting on this indicator will be possible after the data has been morethoroughly analyzed.
The end of project target value is yet to be decided
The figure needs updating and verification of data collected by NRVA during 2007/08. Traget will be set once the projectestablishes the total network in the country, which is not clear presently.

title.narrative: % of difference in price of key consumption and production commodities between at beneficiary villages and in the nearest town

comment.narrative: baseline data proved to have problems and will be modified with a difference method of control versus projects as opposed todifference- in- difference method, which may lack the filter for net attribution

actual.value: Difference in wheat grain prices at local markets at benificiary villages and in the nearest town: 8.0%.Difference in local wheatflour prices at benificiay villages and in the nearest town:8.7%.Difference in kerosene prices at benificiary villages and in thenearest town:7.5%.

comment.narrative: no reliable network data available
The Afghan governments classifies all secondary road as rural roads. We followed the government classification on roads andtherefore, no non-rural road is financed under the project.
no reliable network data available

title.narrative: No. of CDCs/CBOs which manage rural road maintenance

comment.narrative: Target revised to reflect the change in the scope of maintenance
This was dropped during additional financing.

title.narrative: Km of secondary rural roads rehabilitated

comment.narrative: The target has been revised from 1075 to 1105 in November 2010 as part of the Additional Financing Process

title.narrative: Km of tertiary rural roads rehabilitated

comment.narrative: The target has been revised for the second time from (i) 1054 to 1195 in November 2010 as part of the Additional FinancingProcess,(ii) in this mission to add more civil works to be financed out of the potential savings made from completed contracts

title.narrative: Running meters of culverts, retaining walls and bridges to be rehabilitated for secondary roads

comment.narrative: Target revised to focus only on bridge structures

title.narrative: Running meters of culverts, retaining walls and bridges to be rehabilitated for tertiary roads

comment.narrative: Target revised to focus only on bridge structures

title.narrative: # of engineering, social development students which successfully complete internships with NRAP

comment.narrative: target date revised

title.narrative: Km of rural roads, rehabilitated under NRAP, maintained by the communities

comment.narrative: end target adjusted for the second time after having the actual cost of supervision, and maintenance taken into account

title.narrative: An improved and interactive M&E system established at each PIU along with an improved MIS

baseline.value: MRRD & MPW MIS exists but MPW needs considerable improvement

comment.narrative: Improved M&E and MIS, target date revised

title.narrative: A rural access policy and strategy is in place by the MTR

actual.value: Strategy devloped but in draft version.

title.narrative: A maintenance scheme is in place by the end of 2nd year

comment.narrative: target date revised

actual.value: Scheme is in place covering over 2400 km of rural road.

title.narrative: % of reduction in travel time of beneficiaries living along the improved road to first available schools, health care facilities aswell as administrative services

baseline.value: 1 hr for motorized transport2.2 hr for non-motorizedTo district center: 2.1 hourTo hospital: 2.1To school: 12.6 minutes

actual.value: To district center: 0.9 hoursTo hospital: 2.0 hoursTo school: 7 minutes

title.narrative: % of increase in the no. of trips taken by beneficiaries living along the improved road to first available schools, health care facilities as well as administrative services

baseline.value: 58% of population travel to market at least once a day49.9 trips to district centers20.2% of those who were ill went to thehospital2 boys per houshold went to school

actual.value: 64.9 trips to district center.39.8% of those who were ill went to the hospital.1.8 boys per household went to school

title.narrative: Diversification of cropping patterns and income sources of beneficiaries living along the improved road

baseline.value: 68% of population draw income including from off-farm activities.47.2% draw income from off-farm activities.

comment.narrative: data collection has been completed and data analysis is ongoing. The impact evaluation team is working hard to finalize the databefore the grant closing date..
